Basebot v2.1.28 Docs Github

Deploy an AI-powered Chatbot in less than 1 hour


    npm i -g basebot-cli
    basebot create

Why Basebot?

01 Accelerated "Time to Value"

Basebot allows you to start writing business-logic within minutes. All of the integration work is done for you, allowing you to start building value from day one.

We have an ever-growing library of platform connectors, storage modules, authentication methods and more!

02 Extensive platform support

Support multiple platforms from the same codebase!

Basebot acts as an adapter, allowing you to write bot skills that require little-to-no alteration to work with multiple platforms. Need a chatbot that runs on Alexa and your website?

Basebot has you covered.

03 Built and backed by experts

Basebot is built and maintained by ANS. One of the UK's leading Cloud and Digital services providers.

Whether you build with Basebot on your own, or use it as a springboard for an engagement with us, we're always here to help and we're constantly making imrovements and adding features.

Getting Started

Creating a new project

To create a new project, install the basebot CLI tool and run the basebot create command. This will scaffold a new project in your current directory. Fill in the prompts and customise your project to your requirements. You will be asked the following questions:

  • Project Name: your project name (used to create a directory at your current location)
  • Bot Name: The name of your bot. This will potentially be seen by end users.
  • Channels: How users will access your bot. Use <space> to select and <enter> to continue. You can select as many channels as you like.
  • Storage: Where bot-related information will be stored.
  • NLP Engine: What service you want to use for NLP/NLU (optional).
  • Authentication: Any oAuth modules you want to enable. 

        npm i -g basebot-cli
        basebot create
        ? What is your project name? (This will create a folder in your current directory) my-first-bot
        ? What is the name of your bot? Barbara Botface
        ? How do you want people to be able to access your bot? Microsoft Bot Service
        ? What do you want to use for storage? Azure Table Storage
        ? Do you wish to use an NLP service? Microsoft LUIS
        ? (Optional) Do you require any third party authorization support? None

Configuring your environment

Once the create script is complete, you'll find a .env file in the newly-created project folder. This file will contain a number of fields depending on your module selection. These should all be filled in before you can run your app.

In most cases the value you need is self explanatory, for example, AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY would be a secret access key for AWS (usually from an IAM user). However, if you do get stuck, just check the documentation for the module in question (the module that requires said env var is commented above each var). 


        cd my-first-bot
        nano .env #open with your favourite text editor
      

        # Core
        BOT_NAME=Barbara Botface
        USE_LT_SUBDOMAIN=my-first-bot123.localtunnel.me
        DEBUG=basebot*
        
        # AWS Services
        AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=
        AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=
        AWS_REGION='eu-west-1'

Running your app

Once you've filled in your env vars you should be ready to run your app in dev mode. To do this just use the npm run dev command.

No errors? Congrats! you're ready to start writing some code. 


          npm run dev
          [nodemon] 1.19.0
          [nodemon] to restart at any time, enter `rs`
          [nodemon] watching: *.*
          [nodemon] starting `babel-node ./index.js`
